In Julia, You are given a DataFrame `df_cars` with car data with columns `manufacturer` and `model`. Write a function audi_filter that filters down the dataset to only the rows with manufacturer “audi” and model being “a4 or “a4 quattro”, then it should create a new column `audi_a4_type` that equals `true` across all rows. Then return the resulting DataFrame.

To filter the `df_cars` DataFrame in Julia to only include rows with manufacturer "audi" and model being "a4" or "a4 quattro", and then create a new column `audi_a4_type` that equals `true` across all rows, you can use the following function:

```julia
using DataFrames

function audi_filter(df_cars)
    # Filter the data frame to only include Audi A4 and A4 Quattro models
    df_audi = filter(row -> row.manufacturer == "audi" && (row.model == "a4" || row.model == "a4 quattro"), df_cars)
    
    # Create a new column with all values set to true
    df_audi[:audi_a4_type] = true
    
    return df_audi
end
```

This function first filters the `df_cars` DataFrame using the `filter()` function, which applies a predicate (a function that returns a boolean) to each row and keeps only those rows for which the predicate is `true`. The predicate checks if the manufacturer is "audi" and the model is either "a4" or "a4 quattro".

Then, it creates a new column `audi_a4_type` with all values set to `true` by using broadcasting (`[:]`) to assign the value to the newly created column.

To use this function, you would need to have a DataFrame named `df_cars` available in your Julia session. If you already have such a DataFrame, you can apply the function as follows:

```julia
# Assuming df_cars is defined somewhere before this line
result = audi_filter(df_cars)
```

This will return a new `DataFrame` with only the rows that meet the specified criteria and with an additional column `audi_a4_type` set to `true` for all rows.
